segments.text: This is a test.
Today is April 17, 1986.
This is Terry Anderson.
I'm interviewing Frank Wilkinson about his life as a civil libertarian.
Now, you've been involved in that for 40 years, well, since the 1940s, maybe since the 1930s.
Could you tell us something about your early years?
How did you get involved with that?
What in your early years contributed to the fact that you became so involved in the First Amendment, the U.S. Constitution?
I believe that I would mark 1942, spring of 1942, when I first became
active in civil liberties and civil rights work.
At that time I was 28.
I was born in 1914.
I was born in a resort town in northern Michigan, Charlevoix, Michigan.
Moved to Arizona briefly from when I was 3 until 10.
And then moved to Beverly Hills, California through grade school, high school, through UCLA.
My father was a medical doctor, a graduate of Ann Arbor, who was assigned to Arizona during World War I, and then he went into private practice in Hollywood in Los Angeles, Beverly Hills, in 1925.
The question was, what do I attribute to my interest?

I believe that in terms of the ethics which I follow, which I think I would describe today as being essentially materialist, that I think the ethics of my upbringing in some respects are more basic than a more economic or material
analysis that I might have of history today.
I was brought up in a very wonderful family, the youngest of four children.
My brother and sister both became medical doctors.
We were active in the Methodist Church from the time I can first remember all the way through college.
My father was the president of the Protestant
Men's Movement of Southern California.
And my whole life was put into the Methodist Church from the primary grade school, high school, everything.
Somewhere around the beginning of my work at UCLA, my undergraduate work at UCLA, beginning in 1932, I went from just the perspective
limited perspective of the Methodist Church, to become the chair of the board of a group called the Religious Conference Student Board at UCLA.
The board is set up by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, whereby Catholics, Protestants, Jews, free thinkers for that matter, shared the same building.
had offices all but in a common building.
That was a very valuable influence on my life because I had really never met anybody except a Methodist, I think, up until that time.
Politically, the family was very conservative.
I was the head of
for Herbert Hoover in Beverly Hills High School, but the issue there was a Methodist issue.
Hoover was a dry, and Roosevelt was a wet.
My father was a prohibitionist.
I also was the first president of the Hollywood Young People's

of the Women's Christian Templars Union, the WCTU, which was formed in the Methodist Church South in Hollywood, which is the southern branch of the Methodist Church, not my own Hollywood Methodist Church.
All the way through UCLA, I was primarily active as a leader in the Sigma Alpha Epsilon
In fact, I had been pledged to SAE while I was still at Beverly Hills High School.
My brother and my brother-in-law had been SAE.
And I was a very promising campus political person, and so the inducement to get me to join SAE while I was still in high school was that the politics of the fraternities at UCLA

so controlled by the fraternities and sororities that they could tell me that four years from the time I entered that SAE was due to become the fraternity that would produce the student body president.
Well, I was literally offered student body presidency at UCLA four years from the time I matriculated.
And so everything was done to advance me politically on campus to develop my
name recognition.
I probably was a good student, but I was much more interested in social life.
I'm eighty percent deaf, probably about forty percent deaf at that time, and I was so vain that I
was afraid that if I wore a hearing aid that I wouldn't be popular on the campus or with women.
So I went all the way through UCLA without hearing a lecture.
Some jokes about that nowadays.
The reason I turned out all right is that I didn't hear what they were teaching.
But the whole thing was
satisfying my popularity needs, personality needs.
But back of all this was this very, very strong sense of a Methodist conscience, whatever that means.
There was no challenge to a social gospel that I held until after I got out of UCLA, except questions like,
the moral issues like drinking and dancing and smoking and that kind of an issue.
I didn't drink, I didn't smoke, I didn't, those were just moral issues that were involved in my background.
I was pretty active in sports.
I ran a mile in cross country.
at Beverly Hills High School, and I rode on the first UCLA crew, the eight orange shells, my first person in my sophomore year.
When the election came for student body president in 1935, there had been a move made
somewhere on campus, probably by the administration, to require that all students had to become voting members of the associated student body.
From 32 to 35, the only people who joined the ASUC were essentially the fraternities and sororities.
representing about 2,200 students, I imagine.
On 35, the franchise was given to all students as a compulsory part of the fees of matriculation.
And so the whole plan to have me student body president was suddenly confronted with the fact that the majority of the students on campus
were no longer in fraternities and sororities.
Exactly.
The voters.
The voters.
And the university under the provost, Ernest Carroll Moore, was alarmed about this.
He had a lot of confidence in the fraternities and sororities, and particularly in me, and was fearful of the radical students.
on campus to non-organizational students.
Each year the appropriation for the university was subject to question due to some incipient radical activities at UCLA.
So an arrangement was made whereby I was running against a rather popular non-organizational student and
The administration wanted every way possible to have me defeat him.
So two things were done.
First of all, the administration for the first time had a major conference on the question of war or peace, 1935.
This was four years before the outbreak of World War II.
There was a great deal of pacifism, and the university was concerned about pacifism.
I was a religious pacifist, not an economic or radical pacifist.
And so the administration arranged for me to debate this non-organization student.
So the public was here, both of us together, the administration hoping that I would come out ahead and be popular and be elected.
At the same time, some of the
non-organizational students started to have forums on campus which, contrary to university regulations, had no faculty sponsorship.
The university required all campus organizations to have faculty sponsorship, and these forums were deliberately in the face of that, to have no faculty involved, just student-operated

open forums and the administration was against that and I think I was against that but the man who I was running for student body president was one of the leaders in that so the administration saw the opportunity to eliminate almost you might say the opposition to me by expelling those students who were in
the non-faculty represented forums.
And about a month before the election, they held a forum, and five students were expelled, including the candidate against me for student body president.
So I was then a shoe-in.
Two weeks before the election, enormous student protests developed.
the administration was forced to back down and reinstate the students.
And when the election came, I was wiped out.
They had made another martyr.
Interesting about who the five students were that were expelled.
I've often thought about them.
First of all, the manwe were labeling all these people communists or radicals, very
The man I was running against became a law professor at a small college down in Florida.
He, I think today, is the executive director of the Trial Lawyers Association of America.
Very successful, very affluent lawyer.
Another one is a corporation lawyer in Beverly Hills.

A third one, who had been the student body president the year before, half a year before, became a United States Army general and became the, was the director of the Army War College in Washington, D.C. A fourth one went to work for Jimmy Hoffa and the Teamsters Union.
It was a right-hand man, Jimmy Hoffa.
He was killed in some Teamster fire situation some years ago.
And there was a fifth or a sixth was a woman, Celeste Strack, and she did become a communist.
Very interesting.
And today, is that the 36th?
Fifty years.
Fifty years ago.
Fifty years to the day.
I now have served one year in the federal prison on a First Amendment challenge of the Un-American Activities Committee.
Sure.
In a lawsuit, the American Civil Liberties Union, Southern California, is sponsoring on behalf of myself and Carl, the National Committee Against Repressive Legislation, NCARL,
We've learned in the last six years that my life was followed and altered by surveillance and disruption by the FBI from 1942, when I really took my first social concern stand, until 1980.
In the federal district court in Los Angeles last month, the FBI admitted to the judge that they have 132,000 pages of surveillance on me from 1940 to 1980.
And the law firm handling this, which I, my own choice, I had the contacts.
It's the second largest Republican law firm in LA, lobe and lobe.
made up, younger people particularly, have made up with I think this day would characterize as yuppies.
They're really getting an education.
They're handling this all pro bono as volunteer council for ACNU of Southern California.
And we estimate that the FBI spent 17 million dollars on surveillance on me from 1942 to 1980.
And we have a lawsuit now against the FBI
claiming $16 million in damages, as well as injunctive relief to stop it from happening anymore, not only to me, but to the next generations.
I think it's interesting, is that those who are considered most radical, communist, and the kind of witch hunts of the 30s, have turned out to be very conservatives.
And I, who
was the most conservative.
Youth for Herbert Hoover, Sigma Alpha Epsilon for Trinity type, that turned out to be the liberal.
That is interesting.
I wanted to ask you something along those same lines.
In 1942, you began your career along the civil liberties side.
What happened between that period of 36 when you graduated from college, when you were the more conservative candidate, and by the time you went in 1942?
What were some of the variables that came together that obviously disillusioned you or made you much more of a social activist?
Six year period.
turnaround in my life.
It came about as a result of a decision I made in the last year of UCLA.
I'd always thought about it, but I finally decided to become a Methodist minister.
I was quite influenced by a pledge brother of mine, named Lloyd Bridges.
He later became a motion picture actor, Bud Bridges.
He was my pledge brother.
And, interesting enough, Lloyd Bridges became an informer for the Un-American Activities Committee in the 40's, and apparently became a radical, after I knew him at UCLA.
Did he inform on you?
No.
He didn't know me except for my fraternity brother.
He informed on people in the motion picture industry.
I guess with this type of a history, an anecdote, not an anecdote, but a specific will give you the measure of what I was like.
During Halloween 1933, we'll say, when I was about ready to go out of being a pledge to becoming a regular member of S.A.E.
They put us through a great, very rigorous strain, no sleep for seven days, all kinds of nonsense, and work.
And the last night, they sat us down, Bud and me and four or five others who were being blinged, and gave us a sheet of paper with blank words missing.
ask us to fill it out in ten minutes, not to talk to each other.
When I looked at this, every blank word had to do with sexual relationship with a woman.
Here, I'm a virgin and never had intercourse.
I never had intercourse while I was at UCLA.
Very unusual for this generation.
But I looked at these words, I knew the words, I never used them, but I recognized the blank spaces.
And though in great fatigue, I filled in the blanks, holding up to the last minute, and then they pressed me, and I just hurried through and filled it in real quick.
When I came in an hour later to the final meeting with the Supreme Archon, the leaders of the National Fraternity who were there,
They were welcoming me into the fraternity.
How wonderful it was to get a Methodist leader like me.
And it was just all laudatory, but I was on a bright light on my face, a bleak light on my face, and they were all in the dark in the back of the room.
I could not see anybody.
It was kind of a third-degree atmosphere.
And then I heard this voice say, well, wait a minute.
What's this?
What's this?
This man didn't write that.
I thought you said he was a Methodist.
And he went through my overhearing.
And finally a voice came out and said, Frank, I am deeply shocked.
I cannot believe.
Did you sign this paper?
Is this your handwriting?
And I admitted that I had.
And I apologized and said I was very tired.
And at that point, I was told I'd been rejected from membership in SAA, and I broke down and I began to cry.
And then they suddenly turned on the lights, told me it was all a joke, and I was welcomed into the fraternity.
I cried for an hour after that.
The shock was so great.
The embarrassment was so great from having
written those words and being called on it and being denied membership in the fraternity.
I remember walking up and down with Bud Bridges.
He tried his best to stop me from crying.
I just sobbed and sobbed and sobbed.
About that time of the following year, before we graduated, Bud was saying, Frank, you really ought to become a Methodist minister.
And I really thought I should, too.
Now,
this episode put in without your request.
I'm leaning up to the fact that in the summer of 36, as a graduation present from my family, I was given enough money to make a pilgrimage to Bethlehem in Jerusalem.
The idea would be I'd go to the Holy Land in old Palestine and visit and then come back and begin graduate work.
for the Methodist ministry.
It was a wonderful opportunity.
And with another fraternity brother who was also studying for the ministry, we set off for the Holy Land in the summer of 36.
I had never seen any poverty in my life at that point.
That was the seventh year of the American Depression.
I didn't know there were any poor people.
I didn't know there had been a depression.
Didn't you read the newspapers?
I don't have any reaction on that to me from the newspapers.
I certainly read the newspapers, but not too much.
I remember the newspapers at that time, I remember so much the only times attacking Upton Sinclair for being an atheist.
I remember when he was running for
governor of California.
My father was very active in political campaigns, like conservative Republican governors, Republican mayors, things of that kind.
I just didn't know about it.
I, every Saturday and Sunday night, I was dancing and never thought of going out without a tuxedo or tails.
Always dressed up, always having a good time.
little contradiction between that and not drinking.
I never drank, I never smoked, but I went out dancing all the time.
Anyway, I started across the country.
I got one introduction to the problem in December
January 1935-36.

For as the head of the University Religious Conference, the Rausch and Bush Fellowship at UCLA, which is a Baptist group, invited me to represent the student board of the Religious Conference to come to a weekend seminar at Asilomar, Northern California, the YWCA encampment.
I didn't know what it was all about,
When I got up there, I found out that we were going to have a seminar on the life and work of Jane Adams, the settlement house worker from Hull House in Chicago.
And a woman named Muriel Lester, who was a settlement house worker from London, was there to lead us.
And a man named Kagawa from a similar problem, slum work in Tokyo.
was supposed to come.
And we sat there and for two days we heard about the wonderful life of this woman working among the poor in Chicago.
And I decided when I started for the Holy Land that I wanted to see this problem.
I wanted to see poor people.
I was deeply moved by what I heard.
And my whole Christian upbringing was to want to do something about the poor.
The first stop on my trip east was to go into Chicago, look up Hull House.
I came upon Maxwell Street in Chicago in the summer of 1936.
There were tens of thousands of people who were begging.
Poverty I'd never seen in my life.
Unbelievable poverty.
People eating out of garbage cans.
I put in the first ten days I was in Chicago.

I spent all the money that I had budgeted for my first three months of my traveling by taking people literally out of garbage cans and bringing them around to the front of the store and buying them a ten-cent meal.
I had to go through a week before I realized that my dimes were not making an impact on the problem.
There's detail on that we don't need.
I think what you want me to give you is our hurried summer here.
I went from Chicago... Well, that must have had a tremendous impact.
That was a changing point.
That was a changing point.
You feel that was the single most important episode then?
That was the first important episode.
But from then on, the attitude...
There was an author at that time called Richard Halliburton.
who'd written a book about the royal road to romance.

While I was on the way to the Holy Land and all that, I was deeply influenced by the idea of going around the world on a dollar a day, using a sleeping bag, following the route of Hannibal over the Alps, swimming the Bosphorus, all the things that Halliburton did.
It's kind of a smart idea, a junket, fun trip, as well as going
to the Holy Land.
All of that lightheadedness went out in Chicago.
From then on I was just totally changed and almost driven, I think, to what you'd have to say almost like wanting to simulate the life of the poorest of the poor.
I went into Chicago and I'd heard about
all my life.
I'd heard about the Bowery.
The Bowery is a song.
And poor people.
Well, I went into the Bowery, and I came upon the Flophouses of the Bowery.
And I moved in for a month to live in the Flophouses of the Bowery, trying to, again, just live the life of male derelicts.
And then there was overwhelming problems.
This was a second experience.
Meanwhile, my family back in L.A. were absolutely horrified at the letters I was writing home.
They sent my older sister back to pick up a new Packard, which was a car that had been manufactured in Detroit.
Come back to Detroit, pick up a new Packard, come into New York with a foster sister, find me, and bring me home.
with the understanding that I could start over again and travel, as they would have probably said, like a Wilkinson should travel.
My sister had only a post office box in the Lower East Side of New York to find me.
Then she did locate me, and she moved into the fanciest hotel in New York, and by communication we made a date to meet in her hotel room.
I'm giving you details you don't need.
No, I want to hear this.
They wanted me to come home, and I was telling them that I was seeing a world that I'd never seen before, the real world.
And I was seeing Christianity in an entirely different way than we were brought up.
I really felt a challenge, not to just say the
building the kingdom of God on earth as you would in a Lord's Prayer on a Sunday, but you practice it.
It was the desire to practice the teachings of Christ that moved me.
So I did not return home with her, and there were some experiences there.
We were a very close family, but I would not go home.
And I managed to catch a freighter, and the freighter
out of New York.
I didn't care where I went.
I'd go to Palestine either by way of Asia or through the Mediterranean.
I didn't care.
Hopefully the Mediterranean.
But I tried both every day, trying to get a job working on a freighter.
And I finally got on a Norwegian freighter, which I thought had been going to Norway.
Turns out it was going to Marseilles, France.
And when we got across the Atlantic, eleven days of travel,
The boat accidentally dropped me in a small poverty-stricken fishing village in northern Portugal.
It was not even a dock, not a harbor.
The boat's carrying some supplies in by flat bottom barges from the ocean, from the ocean.
And then I was put off the boat.
They needed the space where I was sleeping.
They needed it for business purposes.
So here I am in Portugal, which I learned for the first time was under a totalitarian regime, a man named Salazar.
And I'm trying to get to the Holy Land, and the war in Spain has been going for four months.
And you cannot go through Spain, you cannot go around to North Africa because all the boats were being sunk.
And I went into the embassy, American embassy in Lisbon, to try to get some help.
And I had fantastic credentials.
The number one thing I had was a cable address for the Bank of America for $10,000 on call.
That was a lot of money in those days.
Oh, absolutely.
And then I had a letter from the mayor, and the governor, and the police chief, and the
sheriff and the president of the university, all personal letters in terms of my family and me.
I turned these all into them, and by pure luck there were a group of Portuguese sportsmen, friends of Franco, who they knew, who were going in to spend the weekend with Franco in Seville.
And they had a big limousine, and they
called and got permission for me and my friend to ride with him, and get through to Seville and then go down to Gibraltar from Seville, to cut across the southern end of Spain.
Your friend was still with you?
Oh, yeah.
He was going through changes, but not the same.
So I found myself entering Spain in the fourth month of the Civil War with these wealthy sportsmen, friends of Franco.
At that time,
I mean, Spain was a civil war.
Franco was fighting the Communists.
That was the way I saw it.
I get in there and I find almost no Spanish troops, all German, Nazi, Italian fascists.
Some Portuguese under Salazar there.
And I went through, you know, miles and miles and miles through war zones where the
villages had been torn up and blown up.

And third thing, I think, this is not the way I ever thought about it, but I think going into these villages and seeing these, thatched roof, adobe shacks, and in the middle of them a large Catholic church, really struck me, the poverty and the church.
Why?
And I'm glad that I was a Methodist and not that.
In other words, you were glad you were a Methodist and not a Catholic.
I got into Seville, and the American embassy in Seville was absolutely horrified.
They let me come in because there were no Americans left in Spain.
And they got me out as quick as they could in a taxi cab with a reporter for the London Times who was going from Seville down to Gibraltar.
We had to go through four different army commands to get out of the country, all during wartime.
Very, very tricky.
This reporter for the London Times told us that he was going to make the first report on the extent of not only Nazi and Italian influence under Franco,
But no word of that out yet.
But right in front of the American embassy was a giant Texaco oil company tanker.
And we watched, right in front of our embassy, we watched a hundred German Nazi tanks pull up alongside with the pipes or hoses hung over, filling these German tanks with American Texaco oil.
And he was reporting that.
At that time, Roosevelt
said we were in a policy of non-intervention.
We were supporting either side, and we saw that it was a lie.
Let's drop all that.
I was changing hourly.
Sure.
I get across to Northern Africa, and I'm timing myself.
My goal is to be in Bethlehem for Christmas Eve.
This was about November 1st.
So I
see as much as I can.
I go through Morocco and Algeria and Tunisia and Libya for the Gulf of Cedars.
I was in Tripoli and Benghazi and Derna.
And traveling always as poor as I could.
This desire to be with the poorest of the poor.
Traveling in boxcars with the peasantry.
Anyway, I finally arrived in Egypt two days before Christmas and caught a train on up to Jerusalem across the Sinai Desert.
And I arrived there the morning of Christmas Eve, December 31st.
Please pardon me, December 24th.
And I went immediately out to Bethlehem, or getting out there as quick as I can.
I got out there at dusk.
And when I started getting near the Church of the Nativity, which is, oh, I'm so thrilled with the idea.
My whole idea is the Christmas carols, Little Town of Bethlehem, and Silent Night, Holy Night.
And I get there, and I see these crowds and crowds of people around the entrance to the church.
And I get into those crowds that go in there.
And it turns out that 90% of these crowds were beggars, or begging of pilgrims.
They were barefoot.
They were gunnyside cloth.
They were horribly, horribly poor, as poor as anything I saw in Morocco or Algeria or Tunisia or Libya.
And they were begging for one-tenth of one cent.
And I could not get through the crowds of beggars to get into the church Christmas Eve.
And that was nearly the end of this whole thing.
And I began formulating.
Why 2,000 years of Christianity?
Are there still such a contrast between the teachings of Christ and the practice?
Or 5,000 years of Judaism?
Or 1,200 years of Muhammad of Jerusalem as the center of all three Western faiths?
I spent three months there in the Holy Land.
I'll speed this up for you.
I spent three months there in the Holy Land struggling with my conscience.
I decided early that I would not become a Methodist minister.
I just couldn't see it.
I decided I was going to take the teachings of Christ and either practice them every minute of my life, literally, or I was going to candidly admit my hypocrisy.
I was going to be either a hypocrite openly or an actual practicing Christian.
What I learned in the old city, in Jerusalem, is unbelievable.
You have the tomb of Isaac and Abraham.
You still have virgin births.
The peasants believe that Sarah, the wife of Abraham, has influence with childbearing.
So barren women come there to pray, and hopefully, as a result, God will give them a child.
I saw it, and I was laughing.
My God, it's
the whole idea of the Immaculate Conception falls apart.
By the time I left Jerusalem, I had become an atheist.
Three months.
That's incredible.
I wrote a letter to Robert Gordon Sproul.
Oh, I know, I took a bicycle.
I bought a bicycle in Jerusalem.
An old, old, old beaten-up bicycle.
No, no, uh,
What do you call it?
Pedals.
Pedals, you know, the kind that you, where you get gears, you know.
Yeah, no gears, yeah.
Just old-fashioned bicycle.
Yeah.
And with my fraternity brother, we decided, all right, let's go see Europe.
So we bicycled throughout all of Palestine and all of Syria and Lebanon, and then through Greece and England, Ireland, Scotland, Wales, France,
You know, it took a year.
Covered every country in Europe, finally.
Did your friend also become an atheist?
No.
He became more and more devout, a Christian.
And we began differing, and made our travels together difficult.
Very interesting what happened to him.
Saw the same thing, same background, and react differently.
Yes, that is interesting.
He'd have me go along with him.
He'd go into the various tombs where I believe Christ arose from the dead.
He'd wait until the light would come down through the rocks and have a very expensive camera, and I would take a picture of him praying at Christ's tomb.
He went down to the Jordan, and a Baptist minister baptized him in the Jordan, in the place where Christ was baptized.
And I rode out in a boat to catch him exactly at the moment of baptism.
I was his
These were pictures he was going to take home to help him with his new ministry when he got back, by visit to the Holy Land.
I just thought he was terrible.
And, you know, we argued.
At any rate, on my way from along the coast of Tyre and Sidon up to Beirut on bicycle, I see a sign called the American University outside of Beirut.
And I pull in there, and I go in looking for a library.
I want to see books.
I thought I was the first person that ever doubted there was a God.
And where to look?
Where's the word God?
Where can I find these things?
And I wrote there, wrote a long, long letter to Robert Gordon Sproul, who was the president of the University of California.
And I was his hope, because I was the conservative that was
protecting the appropriations of the state legislature.
And I wrote him, I remember writing, Dear Bob, there is no God.
It's a misunderstanding of the unknown, and so on.
I lived for three months under Mussolini, three months under Hitler.
I lived in the ghetto of Warsaw.
I saw programs in Romania.
I just saw...
things that no mind ever saw.
I really got educated.
I came back to L.A. a year and a half after I left.
Totally changed.
Totally committed to teaching the practice of Christianity, but not wanting to be any part of organized religion.
I went back to that Hollywood Methodist Church, early 1938.
And I remember
making and then bringing new black friends of mine.
I'd never had any touch with racism except as maids in my home up until the trip.
But bringing them to that Hollywood Methodist church, just to shock them.
That church had not accepted Democrats, to say nothing of accepting minorities.
And all the church did was just to say, you pat me on the back and tell my family not to worry.
Everybody was shocked and worried.
Everybody was shocked and worried.
But they were saying, don't worry about Frank.
He'll be all right.
And at that point is where the end of this thing begins.
A Catholic priest in L.A., Monsignor Thomas J. O'Dwyer, Archdiocesan Director of Charities, heard about me and came out to my home in Beverly Hills to talk to me.
I didn't know about what.
And I really let it into him, because I'd seen the role of the Catholic Church in Europe, in Spain.
It seemed to me like the Catholic Church was worse than any of them in terms of its contradiction between teachings and practice.
He didn't argue with me.
He just let me talk.
When I was all through, he simply said, my son, you did not need to go so far to get so excited.
He took me in his car from my home in Beverly Hills, eight miles out to the ghetto of Watts, and showed me housing conditions in Watts equal to what I'd seen in Bethlehem and Jerusalem.
And offered me a job as his secretary for $15 a week to become the, his secretary on a program to make Los Angeles free of slums.
And it was from there,
